Comment:
Incredible film. Powerful and gut-wrenching. My father is a Pentecostal minister in New England, and I‚Äôve grown up in the familiar cloudy-small town church atmosphere my whole life. The themes and feel of this story are genuine; a truly honest depiction of the toiling postmodern Christian culture in the current world. Although my Preacher father wouldn‚Äôt care for its hopelessness, I see how difficult it is for the intellectual, hurting ministers of small churches, in the shroud of mega churches and business culture.... 
the will of God truly is a mystery in such days as this

B. Skirts all morals and ethical purpose
C. Pulls Thomas Merton into the mix-and wrongly so!
D. Portrays people who Believe in Christ as dour, ignorant and boring. As well as ignorant to Climate Change. And many other malicious lies.

Comment:
You know, I know the Oscars are full of hacks who don't know what they're doing. And that's okay. They still serve a purpose! They give smaller filmmakers (like the brilliant Yorgos Lanthimos, director of The Favourite) more recognition. From now on, they won't be a nobody with some good ideas. They'll be an Oscar-winning filmmaker, significantly increasing their budget and creative control.

But the fact that Ethan Hawke wasn't nominated for Best Actor, and would likely not have won even if he did, is absolutely disgusting. For shame, Oscars. For shame.

Comment: I see a lot of comments about this being an "oscar film". I don't think that even matters anymore, except for the bankability of the director / producer and main cast. This film feels different from that, like it's from the seventies: thought-provoking, otherworldly and most importantly, bold. We need more bold cinema now more than ever, no matter how much the truth of certain things can hurt to watch.

Title: First Reformed | Official Trailer HD | A24
Comment: A24's "First Reformed" re-images the Christian film as a terrifying authentic film;  a dark and brutal odyssey from stability to uncertainty to fear. The menacing yet intangible horror that not only Ethan but also Lustmord provides, is an experience that can only to be had in a theatre. There are so many scenes where I sat and pondered with Toller about the authenticity of his dichotomy. The acting is incredibly real, which made the story become a real force of nature on screen and within the mind of the viewer. "First Reformed" was an immensely engaging film on both an emotional and ethical level; constantly combating certainty with uncertainty, anger with expression, and religious duties with love. The metaphors and symbolism runs deep yet not fully reliant. Picking up on them only supplements the uncomforting essence that comes with having faith being put to the test. "First Reformed" is a rare and intriguing example of theological inquiry in American cinema! This movie was raw, bleak, wintry, and downright disturbing! What a fucking movie!

Comment:
It is certainly original and different, great performances by Ethan and Amanda highlight the film. There are serious issues handled too form personal crisis and loss to the environmental problems. There is fantasy like scene where Ethan and Amanda  Float above the stars and the Earth that is surreal for sure. The end, well that is another story reminds me of The Lobster
. First Reformed  was emotionally draining for me and then the surprise end came in like the credits in the Red Wedding Episode in Game Of Thrones.

Comment: I watched it the other day and I can surely say that I was both delighted and not disappointed. It‚Äôs like a perfect combo of Bresson‚Äôs ‚ÄúDiary of a Country Priest‚Äù and Schrader‚Äôs own ‚ÄúAffliction‚Äù. And concerning all the disappointment of films that he‚Äôs made throughout the 2010‚Äôs, I‚Äôm SO goddamn happy that he made this film. It‚Äôs honestly one of his best (right up their with ‚ÄúMishima: A Life in Four Chapters‚Äù and even ‚ÄúTaxi Driver‚Äù). I seriously want to go watch it again and just admire how my favorite screenwriter managed to pull off this spiritual masterpiece of a film. It‚Äôs probably one of the best films I‚Äôve seen in 2018 thus far. Goddamnit, I loved this film.
